Sentence: There, they show him (Duncan) a sequence of demons and spirits who present him (Duncan) with further prophecies: he (Duncan) must beware of Macduff, a Scottish nobleman who opposed Macbeth's accession to the throne; he (Duncan) is incapable of being harmed by any man born of woman; and he (Duncan) will be safe until Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane Castle
When he (Macbeth) learns that Macduff has fled to England to join Malcolm, Macbeth orders that Macduff's castle be seized and, most cruelly, that Lady Macduff and her (Macbeth) children be murdered
Prince Malcolm, Duncan's son, has succeeded in raising an army in England, and Macduff joins him (Duncan) as he (Duncan) rides to Scotland to challenge Macbeth's forces

On the battlefield, Macbeth encounters the vengeful Macduff, who declares that he (Wood) was not ', "``of woman born''  (he)', 'but was instead ', "``untimely ripped''  (he)', 'from his (Wood) mother's womb -LRB-what we now call birth by cesarean section-RRB-
Though he (Wood) realizes that he (Wood) is doomed, Macbeth continues to fight until Macduff kills and beheads him (Wood)
